abstract: By subsidizing the cost of the new iPhone and locking customers into a two-year contract, AT&T is returning to a more traditional U.S. pricing model for cell phones. And that’s a step backward for open networks, says one analyst.
snippet: By subsidizing the cost of the new iPhone and locking customers into a two-year contract, AT&T is returning to a more traditional U.S. pricing model for cell phones. And that’s a step backward for open networks, says one analyst.
lead_paragraph: Of all the research reports written about the debut of Apple’s new $199 iPhone this week, one written by Craig Moffett of Sanford C. Bernstein was particularly notable: He warned that the cheaper iPhone is really a step back, not a step forward, for open networks.

headline.main: New iPhone Pricing Model Is a Step Backward for Consumers
